Popular Search Terms
Nike Flyknit
Nike Flyknit
Nike Flyknit
Lightweight. Breathable. Supportive.
Nike Flyknit technology uses high-strength fibers to create lightweight uppers with targeted areas of support, stretch and breathability.
Shop Now
Nike Flyknit Technology
Inspired by our most common feedback from runners, Nike engineered a fabric that fits like a sock, with the support and durability for sport.
What is Nike Flyknit
A material made up of strong yet lightweight strands of yarn that have been woven into a one-piece upper, securing an athleteâ€™s foot to the shoe platform.
How Nike Flyknit Works
Different types of knit patterns are used within a single Flyknit upper. Certain areas have a tighter weave to give the foot more support, while other areas are designed to be more flexible or breathable. Data from Nikeâ€™s 40+ years of studying the foot determines where each pattern is applied.
Shop Nike Flyknit
Nike Flyknit for Running
Breathable construction and targeted support help you tackle your longest distance.
Shop Now
Nike Flyknit for Basketball
Integrate areas of stretch and support where you need it most.
Shop Now
Nike Flyknit for Soccer
Excellent touch, control and striking power thanks to a sock-like fit.
Shop Now

History of Air
1987: Air Max 1
Inspired by the open architecture of Parisâ€™s Centre Pompidou, Nike Designer Tinker Hatfield cut a small window into the Air Max 1â€™s midsole, making Nike Air visible for the first time.
1990: Air Max 90
With its standout side panel, the AM 90 was a revolution of its own. Its original â€˜Infraredâ€™ colorway still creates a sensation with every reissue.
1995: Air Max 95
Our designers took inspiration from the earthâ€™s layers for the 95â€™s sculptured look. This Air Max shoe was also the first to add a second visible Nike Air unit at the front of the foot.
1997: Air Max 97
The first Air Max shoe with full-length Nike Air cushioning, the 97 looks incredibly futuristic. But our designers actually took their inspiration from the natural beauty of ripples in water.
2015: Nike Air VaporMax
With only a thin film separating your foot from the cushion, this shoe is the closest you can get to walking on air. The Air VaporMax is fast, flexible, and impossible to miss.
2018: Air Max 270
Boasting the first-ever Max Air unit created specifically for Nike Sportswear, the AM 270 delivers an Air unit that absorbs and gives back energy with every springy step.
2023: Air Max Pulse
Inspired by the grime music scene, the Pulse brings an underground feel to the iconic Air Max line with an edgy colorway, vacuum-sealed accents, and point-loaded cushioning.

How to Find the Right Nike Sports Bra Size for You
Buying Guide
A Nike sports bra technical designer weighs in on how to measure your sports bra size and select a style for the best fit and feel.
Last updated: November 15, 2023
7 min read
For many athletes, sports bras are a crucial part of every workout outfit. This is because a sports bra is one of the most technical clothing items athletes can own, explained Tara Sweeney, a Nike sports bra technical designer.
But the ideal fit comes down to more than just measurements. â€œFinding the right sports bra comes down to striking a balance between comfort and support for your breast size and firmness, body type and intended activities,â€ said Sweeney.
For more on finding the right fit, Sweeney shared how to calculate your bra size, as well as how to choose a Nike sports bra for different activities.
(Related:
The Best Nike High-Support Sports Bras To Try
)
How to Measure Your Nike Sports Bra Size
According to Sweeney, in order to correctly measure yourself for a Nike sports bra, try to wear an unlined, lingerie-style bra that allows for some separation between the breasts.
Start by measuring your underbust (around the braâ€™s bottom band, just under the breast). Then, measure your cup.
â€œFor Nike sports bras, you will need to take a cup measurement,â€ she said. â€œThis means you start from the center of your chest between the breasts and measure over the fullest point of the breast while keeping the tape measure parallel to the floor and ending where the breast tissue ends at the side.â€
Use this measurement tool to get started.
Find Your Bra Size
Find your bra size with this two-step quiz. Before you start, wear an unlined bra that supports your natural shape â€” no bralette or padded bra.
(1/2)
First, Measure Your Underbust
Measure around the braâ€™s bottom band, just under the breast. The tape measure should feel snug. Round up to the closest measurement.   If you donâ€™t have a measuring tape, use a string and a ruler. Follow the above instructions. Lay the string on a flat surface and measure with the ruler.

Second, Measure Your Cup
With the tape measure parallel to the floor, lay the tape across the fullest point of your breast. Measure from the center of your chest to where your breast tissue ends on one side (where an underwire should sit). Round up to the closest measurement.

3 Ways to Tell If Your Sports Bra Fits
To ensure your bra fit is perfect, in the fitting room (or your own home), try this quick, three-step test.
1. Check the Straps
â€œThe straps are critical in creating a balanced fit,â€ explained Sweeney. â€œThey help provide tension on the neckline and underarm area to help distribute the breast weight and alleviate pressure on the bottom band.â€
Here are a couple signs that Sweeney said might indicate youâ€™re not wearing the right size:
The bra might be too big
if you constantly feel the need to adjust the straps, or if the straps are sitting far out on your shoulders.
The bra might be too small
if the straps are putting pressure on the neck and there is excessive (and visible) cutting or digging in the shoulders.
Adjustable straps are a useful way to customize the fit of a sports bra, but Sweeney advised that tightening them should not be used as a fix for a sports bra that doesnâ€™t fit properly in other areas, such as â€œthe cup being too big or the band being too loose.â€
2. Assess the Bandâ€™s Tightness
When it comes to functionality, the bottom band of a sports bra is the garmentâ€™s MVP, noted Sweeney. â€œItâ€™s the foundation of any bra, so it should fit snugly against the rib cage directly below the bottom of the breast tissue,â€ she said. â€œ[The band] should feel firm but not cause discomfort. Donâ€™t forget you have to breathe in this!â€
To indicate proper fit, see if you can comfortably place two fingers under the band while wearing it. Here are some additional tips:
The bra is likely too big
if the band moves up and the cup area feels unsupported and loose when you raise your arms.
The bra is likely too small
if the band feels so tight that itâ€™s difficult to take deep breaths and freely move.
3. Mimic The Activity You Plan to Do In The Bra
A bra should help make you feel more confident in your activity or sport. The best way to test for that, said Sweeney, is to duplicate whatever movements youâ€™ll do while wearing it, whether thatâ€™s moving through your favorite yoga flow or settling into a deep squat. â€œAsk yourself what will make you most comfortable in your activity,â€ she added.
â€œSports bras arenâ€™t one-style-suits-all,â€ she explained. For example, consider two people with the exact same band and cup size practicing yoga. One may prefer a light-hugging sports bra that allows for natural movement in both breasts, while the other might want a snug, high-neckline sports bra to prevent slippage during inverted poses.
One option isnâ€™t necessarily better than the other. The way your sports bra fits and moves with you should be as individualized as you are.
Finding the Best Bra Size: Additional Fit Factors to Consider
Although strap and band fit tend to provide the most clear signs that a bra correctly fits, a few other indicators can signal the wrong size, said Sweeney:
A bra that is too small will often:
Have a neckline and/or underarm area that causes the breast to spill or cut out of the sides of the bra
Feature a neckline and/or underarm area that sits too low on the body
Contain a cup area that is too short, which can cause the bottom band to ride up and sit on the bottom of the breast rather than just below the breast tissue
A bra that is too big will often:
Show excess fabric bunching or gathering throughout the cup area
Have a neckline and/or underarm area that sits too high, potentially rubbing the neck or underarm and causing chafing
Not provide any compression or support, or allow for too much breast movement
Find the Right Nike Sports Bra For You
Here are the four key types of Nike sports bras, plus how theyâ€™re designed to feel on the body:
1. Nike Alate: For a Second-Skin Feel
These bras are designed to feel like a second skin, with soft, non-constricting fabric and a frictionless design that allows the breasts to move in a natural motion. You can choose from varying levels of coverage, like the Alate Minimalist, which has super thin straps and a low-profile design, or the Alate Curve, which features a higher neckline and lower band.
Shop Nike Alate Bras
View All
2. Nike Swoosh: For Snug, Distraction-Free Support
If youâ€™re the type of athlete who wants a no-frills sports bra that will ensure a snug fit, little breast movement, and adequate support for a wide range of activities, the Nike Swoosh sports bra is for you. With a range of necklines and the ability to choose between padded and non-padded varieties, wearers can minimize distractions while taking part in their favorite activity.
Shop Nike Swoosh Bras
View All
3. Nike Indy: For Freedom of Movement & Expression
With a range of necklines (V-neck, U-neck and longline) and bold colors and designs, the Nike Indy sports bra is inherently playful and expressive. This bra is meant to accentuate and hug your body shape, with adjustable straps and removable cups.
Like the Alate bras, these tend to allow the breasts to move in a freer, less restrictive motion, but are still dynamic for all types of movement. Adjustable straps and removable cups allow for further customization.
Shop Nike Indy Bras
View All
4. Nike Alpha: For a Personalized, High-Support Fit
Similar to the Nike Swoosh sports bra, Nike Alpha sports bras are designed for extra support and bounce reduction. They feature extra-wide straps that are adjustable so you can make the bra truly your own. Youâ€™ll also find styles with a front-facing zipper for easy removal.
Words by Julia Sullivan, A.C.E.-certified C.P.T.

Space Hippie
There Is No Resupply Mission on Mars (or Earth)
Space Hippie is an exploratory footwear collection inspired by life on Mars
â€”where materials are scarce and there is no resupply mission. Created
from scraps, or â€œspace junk,â€ Space Hippie is the result of sustainable
practices meeting radical design.
There Is No Resupply Mission on Mars (or Earth)
Space Hippie is an exploratory footwear collection inspired by life on Marsâ€”where materials are scarce and there is no resupply mission. Created from scraps, or â€œspace junk,â€ Space Hippie is the result of sustainable practices meeting radical design.
Get to know the team (and the science) behind Space Hippie, and see how
weâ€™re sourcing, making and redefining our goals behind the products we
design.
Get to know the team (and the science) behind Space Hippie, and see how weâ€™re sourcing, making and redefining our goals behind the products we design.
Fit For Every Athlete*
Each of Space Hippieâ€™s four silhouettes provide a unique fit optionâ€”
traditional laces, lace-less and Flyeaseâ€”for the lifestyle of city athletes* on
-the-go.
Be among the first to know when the Nike Space Hippie Collection drops.
Explore All Launch
Fit For Every Athlete*
Each of Space Hippieâ€™s four silhouettes provide a unique fit optionâ€”traditional laces, lace-less and Flyeaseâ€”for the lifestyle of city athletes* on-the-go.
Be among the first to know when the Nike Space Hippie Collection drops.
Explore All Launch
Made with Space Waste Yarn
One athlete's trash is anotherâ€™s treasure. Space Hippieâ€™s Flyknit yarn is
made from 85-90% recycled content, including plastic bottles, t-shirts and
post-industrial scraps.
Made with Space Waste Yarn
One athlete's trash is anotherâ€™s treasure. Space Hippieâ€™s Flyknit yarn is made from 85-90% recycled content, including plastic bottles, t-shirts and post-industrial scraps.
Crater Foam tooling uses about 12% Nike Grind rubber combined with
foam materials for a more sustainable, lightweight and responsive feel
during city exploration.
Weâ€™re working to ditch the double box, and ship Space Hippie shoes in a single shoebox made with at least 90% recycled content.
Weâ€™re working to ditch the double box, and ship Space Hippie shoes in a single shoebox made with at least 90% recycled content.
Our apparel teams carried this inspiration into their design and turned 100% recycled content into Space Waste Yarn to create the Space Hippie tee.
Shop Sustainable Apparel
Our apparel teams carried this inspiration into their design and turned
100% recycled content into Space Waste Yarn to create the Space Hippie
tee.
Shop Sustainable Apparel
A Radically Different Future
Protecting the future of sport starts with reimagining the ways in which we
create the products we love the most. Space Hippie is Nikeâ€™s latest step
toward a better future, but we must work as a team to move the world
toward climate action.
Nikeâ€™s journey toward zero carbon and zero waste to help protect the future of sport.

Letâ€™s Run Together
The Nike Run Club App has everything you need to start running, keep running, and enjoy running more. Never laced up? We got you. Need a coach to keep pace or a friend to keep you company? Nike React foam is nothing short of revolutionary, thanks to its ability to be incredibly responsive and soft. Now, weâ€™re using it to help reach our newest goal: To reduce running-related injuries. And The Nike React Infinity Run, which was designed to help reduce injuries, is the first step toward that north star. With 24% more React foam than Nike Epic React Flyknit 2, it has a wider base to provide more stability and a distinct â€œrockerâ€ shape to roll you through a fluid foot strike. Scroll to learn more about what makes React foam so unique.
Shop All
Designed to Help Reduce Injury
Introducing the Nike React Infinity Run
Shop
Designed to Help Reduce Injury
Introducing the Nike React Infinity Run
Shop
Itâ€™s Incredibly Versatile
When we released our first shoe with Nike React foam in June 2017, we knew it was groundbreaking. But no one at Nike could have predicted how versatile React foam would prove. You can find it now in shoes that range from basketball and running to golf and training. It even adds more comfort to our most stylish sportswear shoes.
Our Most Complete Foam
Responsive. Durable. Soft. Lightweight. â€œHistorically, cushioning innovations might deliver big leaps in one or maybe two aspects of performance,â€ says Nikeâ€™s Ernest Kim, Advanced Director, Global Running Footwear. â€œBut with Nike React, we see significant advancements in all dimensions of cushioning: impact attenuation, energy return, lightweight, and durability. Thatâ€™s why we call it our most complete foam ever.â€
Seriously Durable
A tricky thing about foam: Itâ€™s very rare that you get cushioning thatâ€™s soft and durable. Itâ€™s usually one or the other because those qualities are opposites. But Nike React technology is different. It stayed strong and soft after serious machine testing that mimicked the forces of longtime use.
Lightweight and Soft
We figured out a way for this foam to be soft, but not at the expense of being heavy. We combined polymersâ€”Thermoplastic elastomers (TPE) and Ethylene Vinyl Acetate (EVA)â€”to achieve this truly special effect.
Learn More About The Science Behind the Nike React Infinity Run
To see if the shoe could help reduce injury compared to our motion control shoe, we commissioned a study through the British Columbia Sports Medicine Research Foundation where runners followed a 12-week variable training program ending in a half marathon. Based on the results, we think weâ€™re on the right track: In testing*, the Nike React Infinity Run showed a 52 percent lower injury rate compared to the Nike Structure 22, our leading motion control shoe. Watch Nike Sports Research Labâ€™s Matt Nurse explain the design and testing of this shoe.
*The Nike React Infinity Run reduced running injuries by 52% compared to the Nike Air Zoom Structure 22 in a study of 226 men and women during a 12 week run training program (injury = missing 3 or more consecutive runs due to running related pain). Our study found that 30.3% of Nike Air Zoom Structure 22 runners experienced an injury but only 14.5% of Nike React Infinity Run runners experienced an injury.

Frequently Asked Questions
What is Nike Membership?
Nike Membership is access to the very best of Nike through any of our apps, exclusive products, and Member-only experiences. Nike Members also enjoy free shipping on orders of $50 or more, 60-day Wear Test, and receipt-less returns. Itâ€™s free and easy to join.
Sign Up.
Am I a Nike Member?
Maybe! If youâ€™ve ever logged into a Nike app, then yes, yes you are. Welcome back! If not, letâ€™s change that.
Sign Up.
Is Nike Membership free?
100% yes. Members enjoy all the benefits of Nike Membership at no cost, because once youâ€™re in, we got you. Zero money gets you access to all of it.
Sign Up.

Popular Search Terms
Nike x NBA
Become a Nike x NBA ID Member
Nike x NBA
Air Time: Watch NBA the Nike Way
We've partnered with the NBA to launch Air Time: a new way to broadcast NBA games that takes the fandom beyond the court and into basketball culture.
This time, we've got a special program to celebrate Kobe's impact on today's league. Get an exclusive look into the evolution of Kobe's most iconic sneakers as hosts and special guests take us through his most unbelievable performances. Tune in on Thursday, August 22 at 5PM PST to lock into Kobe's greatest on-court moments, special trivia, and Kobe memories.
Become a Nike x NBA ID Member
Air Time Rewind
Our first Air Time tipped off on November 28th as we watched the Boston Celtics defeat the Chicago Bulls in In-Season Tournament Group Play. We celebrated the Nike NBA 2023-24 City Edition Jerseys with special guests from the Nike Family: Tyrese Haliburton, Napheesa Collier, Vince Carter, Dawn Staley, and Deon Point. In addition to free access to Air Time, Nike x NBA ID Members get exclusive access to product, content, and experiences.
Airtime returned on March 7th as we celebrated Devin Booker's first signature shoe, the Book 1. We watched the Phoenix Suns take down the Toronto Raptors with our hosts, Alexis Morgan, Kenny Beecham, and Jamierson Green live from Nike's NYHQ and tapped in with Coach John Calipari, Shawn Marion, and Book 1 Designer, Benjamin Nethongkome. We talked all things Book and capped it off with a limited Book 1 'Mirage V2' restock where tuned-in Nike x NBA ID Members had a head start on the drop.
Link Accounts
Going Beyond the Game
We're bringing the conversation on basketball culture to the live action of NBA games with the athletes, gear, and stories that have shaped our love for hoops. Check up with our hosts, Alexis Morgan, Kenny Beecham, and Jamiersen Green alongside special guests and voices from across the Nike Basketball universe as they drop in-game announcements, products, and more.
NBA is the Home
of Air Time
Download the NBA App to watch Air Time and get a free preview of League Pass on select game days after becoming a Nike x NBA ID Member.
Download NBA App

Download the Nike App to make sure you catch all the latest Nike x NBA ID Member benefits.
